text: so how's it going everyone a quick
question is anyone ever or can you raise
your hand if you've submitted a PR with
a release note nice feel for sure
so I'm Mara paya on slack and on github
on twitter I'm Mike Arpaio because Mar
Pi was taken so you know nice to meet
you all in person I was on the release
team for 111 112 and 113 working on
release notes and I wrote this I wrote
the outline of this deck well copy
editing the release notes document for
113 so I also edited out all the snark
afterwards but so if you're not familiar
I want to just go through the developer
process for submitting release notes and
then offer some tips and tricks that you
might not be aware of about how you can
you know change the way you write
release notes that makes the release
team's life easier and makes your
release note higher quality so the
process if you're not familiar if you've
ever created a PR against kubernetes
looks a little like this and there is
like whole wall of text and you kind of
have to go through and fill in all of
the questions that it asks you and all
the way at the bottom there's a little
block that says back-to-back-to-back
tech release - note empty space and if
you have a release note you can fill it
in there and if you don't have a release
note ideally you write the word nun now
if you don't write the word nun this
happens and you get the bot saying like
hey you have to either write a release
note or use the prowl command release
note none so you do that and that's
awesome and all of this is outlined on
this document in kubernetes community
repository which isn't super
discoverable but I guess that's a
problem with a lot of kubernetes
Community documents sometimes so
generally everyone does this and towards
the end of the release what happens is
there's some tooling that we have that
goes through and iterates through all of
the pull requests that have landed in
master from the last release to when we
want to cut the new release and it kind
of parses through them looks at each
commit sees if the PR that introduced
that commit has a release note pulls as
many labels as we can from that PR and
then tries to generate a document that's
as contextualized as possible given all
the labels that you add
everything we can infer from her pull
request that's the process now for the
tips and tricks so one thing you might
not know about release notes is that you
can edit your note after your PR has
been merged so you know pre I'd say
before 1:12
the note that is in that was in your PR
used to make it into the actual commit
message in master that's no longer the
case
but either way all of the tooling that
generates release notes documents pulls
the note text from your PR at the time
of document generation which is usually
at the end of their release so if you
land a PR early in their release and you
don't like the release note text
feel free to go and change it the other
thing is write like you're from the
future so this is an interesting thing
that I've thought about a lot as I've
changed the tense on various words in
people's people's release notes over
time but when you write your PR you
write as if you're from you know it's
very you know if this diff has merged
this will happen and stuff like that
you're writing about the future but what
you have to consider is that when a user
is going to be reading a release note
they're going to be reading it in the
future in several months from now so
right you know things in the past tense
this thing was bumped not you know when
this PR is merged it will be bumped and
stuff like that so you know I had a
counter as I was going through this last
releases notes and you know this is in
order of the top amount of things that I
changed now I do have some tooling to go
and edit these automatically but it's
not always you know you can't always
update you can always change update to
update it doesn't always work out that
way the other thing that I would implore
you to do is use more sig and kind
labels if you can so your sig if you add
like slash sig costs per lifecycle
that'll show you know categorize your
note in the cluster life cycle section
of the document if you had multiple
SIG's that's a little less helpful for
the release of the document but still
help more helpful than no SIG's and then
you know there are several kind labels
that you can use that'll add your note
to various
sections of the document which is super
useful the last bits are don't write
notes for non user-facing changes now
the text and the release notes document
says is your feature or do you want to
document any user facing changes so you
know don't be afraid to release no none
and you know capitalize the first letter
of the sentence it's always useful
always helpful and finally use markdown
formatting so if you're referencing a
new flag that's being added or something
like that
wrap it in back ticks and all that good
stuff so that's it with three seconds
left so thank you
